posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
EXTRELIGIOUSLY IMPORTANT MESSAGE FROM THE FRC WEB COMPONENTS TEAM:

The FRC Web Components 2025 Release is here! We’re excited to announce the latest evolution of our web-based dashboard platform.  

This year, we’ve completely refactored and re-engineered the dashboard app. Now uses React for rendering and Redux for state management. Previously relied on custom stuff and some lesser-known libraries. Switching to a software stack that’s more familiar and approachable. Long-term benefits for ourselves and the open-source project.  

Features:
- More flexible layouts
- Add components directly from sources
- Grid layout support
- Component conversion tool
- Properties and sources system
- Plugin API improvements
- Built-in example layouts
- Plugin examples for React and Svelte

Thanks for viewing!

link_counts.title: Elastic 2025: A Lot of Little Things
GitHub - caplin/FlexLayout: Docking Layout Manager for React
Redux - A JS library for predictable and maintainable global state management | Redux

posts.cooked: I love FWC. I hope my students will try to make their own webpage in it to have a "custom" dashboard. Thank you for your work on it!

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: I’ve been longing for something like this for a while. What I would really love is the ability to deploy it to a robot out of the box and hosting an HTTP server on the RIO to access the dashboard.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: The ability to deploy it to a robot out of the box and hosting an HTTP server on the RIO to access the dashboard. Put it in the deploy directory, start a webserver at https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/net/WebServer.html, and Bob’s your uncle!

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: I might give it a try! (though we're cpp team) My hesitation was that there might be non-trivial server-side code running here in the desktop version.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/cpp/classwpi_1_1_web_server.html

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: I was looking it up on my phone and goofily searched “Http” and “Server” (coming up with nothing) forgetting that it starts with “Web.”

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
This is a great idea! It is technically possible to do this by hosting a web server mentioned by Peter_Johnson. Here’s an example of this working:

An image with a download link titled "image" was successfully uploaded. Another image with a different filename "another_image" was also successfully uploaded. Both images have high resolutions and large file sizes (ranging from 1356×572 to 690×179 pixels). The largest file exceeds 9MB, which may cause issues with limited network bandwidth during competitions. However, since these are static assets, they only need to be downloaded once when the robot connects. Additionally, caching the files ensures minimal initial downloading. For optimal performance, consider using a smaller version of the dashboard specifically for display purposes only, without editing capabilities, and allow exporting layouts as downloadable files that can be deployed directly.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: Sweet yeah, I will definitely experiment with this with some simulated bandwidth limiting over wifi. So what would I need to add to the dashboard directory—is that the same as the dashboard directory in the source or do I need to install packages via a full npm installation locally first?

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked: I found this to be a turn off for would-be developers looking to contribute. This is a pity as Lit uses open web standards. Still slick work.

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text, formatted as a single, coherent paragraph with proper grammar and punctuation:

A new release with support for "Release FWC Dashboard 2025.2.0" has been created. You can save the layout as an HTML file using the "Export for Web..." feature from the file menu. The file should be saved inside the folder containing the fwc build within the deploy directory. An example robot project is available at [GitHub repository link]. Save the HTML file to the `src/main/deploy/dashboard` folder. Run in Sim and you should be good to go. Note: This is still experimental and the build hasn’t been optimized for hosting from the Roborio. It’s still a 9MB monster and has most of the editing capabilities of the dashboard app. Also, this feature doesn’t currently support plugins.

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked: I was conflicted about moving away from lit, though I favor web components over libraries like React. I had hoped Lit would gain more traction since starting the project in 2020, yet adoption has been slow. Still, even though the dashboard app is now built with React, you can continue using Lit, Svelte, and other web component frameworks to create components and plugins, at least theoretically, given the availability of various supporting frameworks.

posts.name: Gavin Kistner
posts.cooked: Thank you for reaching out. I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to assist with debugging the issue. Regrettably, I cannot provide further guidance on accessing the repository, and I am unsure why the initial step appears unclear. Additionally, I wonder if there is a missing component or if `pnpm dev` is intended to function differently than expected.

link_counts.title: v1.2 .dmg does not work on macOS · Issue #20 · frc-web-components/app · GitHub
Cannot figure out how to launch the dashboard · Issue #192 · frc-web-components/frc-web-components · GitHub

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
Hi Phrogz, I'm sorry for the trouble. I've been told that macOS testing hasn't been extensive, and I appreciate your efforts in debugging. Here's an overview of what you might see:  
A macOS app requires signing and notarizing, accessible via [this link](https://v1.tauri.app/v1/guides/distribution/sign-macos/). To bypass this, I used `xattr -d com.apple.quarantine /path/to/app/FRC\ Web\ Components.app`.  

You're using either an Apple Silicon Mac or an Intel one? I mainly tested with an M2 MacBook Pro, so results may vary.  

The documentation is confusing, but I'll improve it. Running `pnpm dev` builds dependencies needed for the dashboard, while `pnpm dashboard:dev` starts it using Vite.  

For the Tauri app, visit [this GitHub repository](https://github.com/frc-web-components/app) to access the FRC Web Components dashboard. You'll need Rust and npm installed, followed by `npm install` and `npm run tauri:dev` to launch. I'll also add developer docs soon.

link_counts.title: GitHub - frc-web-components/app: Tauri app for FRC Web Components dashboard

posts.name: Antônio Miranda De Assis
posts.cooked:
EXTRAORDINARILY IMPORTANTLY, DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION.  

The text is:  
Hello, how are you, Amory? I was looking through all your documentation about **FRC** WEB Components, because I’m working on a robot project that needs a front-end with a dynamic and complete interface. I’m using Studica Robotics Hardware, which in general all the programming is the same as **FRC**, but it only supports VScode and WPILIB version 2020. My current problem is that I can’t pull the encoder values to run on my front-end. Do you have an example just to pull the value?

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked: Hello @toninhowow, are you interested in using our app or building a custom dashboard using our component library? Our dashboard uses NetworkTables version 4.1, which isn't compatible with older WPILib versions that use NetworkTables 3. Since we use websockets, the dashboard communicates directly with an NT4 server. Previously, with NT3, additional tools like pynetworktables2js were required. If you're interested, I can help create a plugin to connect with an NT3 server using pynetworktables2js. Alternatively, I can guide you on setting up a React, Svelte, or similar web-based project using the component library and pynetworktables2js.

link_counts.title: GitHub - robotpy/pynetworktables2js: Forwards NetworkTables traffic to a web page, allowing you to write custom dashboards for your robot using HTML/Javascript

posts.name: Antônio Miranda De Assis
posts.cooked: I am interested in creating a custom dashboard. I have successfully programmed a Robot using the 2020 version of WPILib. In my Weber interface, I set up the Operator’s camera using a simple action stream via USB port 1181 along with the robot’s IP address. Additionally, I integrated a JavaScript function to capture images and display the date and encoder values, which are precomputed in millimeters by the robot’s programming. However, I am unsure how to retrieve the encoder value. I explored pynetworktables2js, installed it in my Weber project, and also incorporated the FRCWebComponents script you shared. Could you please guide me on the next steps?

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
